Keshav Bhaiya
Pratyush Pandey
Feb 28, 2020
1 min read
Hailing from Mathura, Keshav bhaiya came to IIT through family recommendations and has been with us for over 4 years.

Officially the groundsman at the sports office seldom lets his assigned responsibilities limit his contribution to sports at IIT Delhi as he juggles responsibilities helping students and staff with their clerical and other administrative sports problems. Recognized as one of the most versatile and hardest working employees, he hasn't let his personal lack of sporting abilities affect his enthusiasm for fostering a better sports culture at IIT Delhi.
To no one's surprise, Keshav bhaiya is the popular guy of the office liked and adored by his colleagues.
Even the workaholic Keshav bhaiya cites lunch with his friends the favorite part of his day.

Throughout his time in IIT, he says his experience with colleagues and seniors has been amazing, particularly, he's grateful for their belief in him, and the opportunities afforded for him.
May Keshav Bhaiya make everyone's life happier, and be the glue which holds the sports office together.
#Sportech20
#bachpan
#banakhelse
#humans
This was post by Humans in association with
@sportech.iitd

Cyclewale Bhaiya
Pratyush Pandey
Oct 1, 2019
2 min read
Ramashray Bhaiya is one of the 17 heavenly creatures you seek when you're dashing headlong for your 8:00 a.m classes.
After a very strenuous morning, he's massaging his knees and waiting for his battery rickshaw to be fully charged when we meet him.

Ramashray Bhaiya greets us with a broad smile as we begin with our spree of questions.
.
"How did you end up at IIT Delhi ?"
.
He starts with contentment, "I hail from a very decent family in Unnao, my brother is the pradhan of a village, he told me about this project being started at IIT. Sumitri Saheb started it, as far as I remember. Saheb told us that our job is permanent, so I agreed. And it's been 19 years since then, in the service of students." Ramashray Bhaiya wipes his forehead as he speaks.
Sun glares at us with even greater vigour.
.
When we start about his family and his life, the content in his voice gave away to forlornness, and he continues,
.
"I live in Katwaria Sarai. My family is settled in the village, and I can't afford to keep them with me in a meagre earning of 9000 per month. It's hard to cook alone for yourself every day but can't help it.
I realised the due importance of education when I came to IIT and put my children in a school. I even enrolled my daughter in coaching for some exam I don't remember now.
लड़की को पढ़ा तो दिया पर नौकरी नहीं लग पायी, हम घूस कहाँ से देते अफसरों को. "
The pain in his last words is quite apparent, and in a very subtle way he adds,
"I feel that IIT has been good with us, but somewhere along the line, we have been neglected.
We run on the same rates as of 2013, we didn't get sufficient e-rickshaws after several promises, neither do the authorities pay heed to us when we voice our concerns, may it be the rates or some random auto-rickshaw, cutting our daily income to an even greater extent. I can't opt for a different job at this age, my knees have given up after 19 years of toil."
.
Ramashray Bhaiya stands up, like a saviour who has been fighting hard for a better life.
.
"One last thing, what keeps you here despite such problems?"
.
"यहाँ के बच्चे.

वो हमको भैया कहते हैं, हम उनको भैया कहते हैं "
•
And he walks away.
(Due to personal concerns, Bhaiya asked us not to put up his picture online.

We respect that.)
#Humans
#HumansOfIITD

Nescafe Bhaiya
Pratyush Pandey
Sep 18, 2019
2 min read
People often forget that just like students, there also exists another group of people that step into a new part of their life after coming to IIT.

Mr Kailash Choudhary, having roots from Bihar but born and raised in Delhi, started a new phase of his life here at IIT Delhi seven years ago. Mr Kailash works at Nescafe during the night hours, and students who usually study late in the library are sure to have met him.
He works from 6 pm - 5 am everyday, due to which he has to take time during the day to sleep. This makes his job harder than it looks, as such a strange work schedule makes it difficult for him to try new things or give time for his hobbies. Still, he seems to love his job here at IIT. When asked for a reason, his reply was simple - “Respect”. “Students here at IIT Delhi have a habit of talking to everyone with respect. For example, Guard Sahab”. He sells around 50 brownies, 150 muffins and 400 to 500 cups of coffee a day. Apart from work, he really loves playing cricket and is a fan of Sachin.
When asked about an incident here at IIT Delhi that he’d never forgotten, he shared a quite humorous event he had. He said, “I was working both shifts during that time, day job at someplace else and night job here at Nescafe. I hadn’t slept for 24 hours straight and was really exhausted, so it was around 1:00 a.m when I dozed off, my partner went to the restroom for a while when a girl came to buy something while I was sleeping. She tried to wake me up and thinking that it was my partner who was doing that, I blabbered some stuff while being half asleep. I later realized that it was a customer and had to apologize.

She thought that I was drunk.” The next time you are at or around Nescafe when he’s working, take a moment to go chat with him, for his best stories are also the ones we cant write
#Humans
#HumansofIITD

Amul Bhaiya
Pratyush Pandey
Sep 14, 2019
2 min read
"I completed my intermediate and took admission in B.A.

soon afterwards. The village didn't give enough opportunities to make the ends meet, and income generated from farming was also insufficient. Owing to the financial crunch, I dropped out of B.A. and came to Chandigarh where I worked for an year in the manufacturing sector. Later, I came to Delhi to work with the help of my relatives. My father in law's friend, who lived in the same locality, happened to be the owner of Amul Shop, and he offered me a job here.
Initially, when I came to Delhi I was very scared of the traffic jams and huge crowds. I still recall an incident when I walked through the roads with my bags over my head to meet my wife because I couldn't bear the traffic jam in the way. One fond memory which I still cherish is my visit to the zoo in Delhi when I was in 9th Class. I still remember a monkey who made unique gestures with an unusual voice.
IIT Delhi has been a wonderful experience so far, among all the items we sell Pizza Kulcha is the one I like the most. It's also the most sold product besides tea, of course, of which we sell around 600-700 cups a day. I have a shift of 12 hours in general, but I prefer a continuous 24-hour shift so that we can relax the next full day. We take breaks while working so it becomes easier to work for that long.
Most of the free time I get is spent in playing with and teaching my small children who are in playgroup.

It's been two and a half years since I started working at IIT Delhi, and students and professors remain our usual customers; it's always good to see them leave satisfied with our shop."
#Humans
#humansofiiitd

Kamla Aunty
Pratyush Pandey
Aug 4, 2019
1 min read
"Bad times are a part of life.

They come and go. The important thing is to stay happy with what you have." This is the philosophy that Kamla Aunty, who runs the tiny tea stall stacked behind the SBI outlet follows. Most of the students and professors stroll right past it, bustling in and out of LHC.
She lives in Gurugram and travels every day to open her shop at 9.30 AM. For many bank employees, it is their day's first cup of tea. Its a place for students to go after their classes get finished. "I opened the shop back in 1998, and I haven't changed a thing about it yet. My husband used to work at this bank before that. While he is no more, I like this place and the people here. I have a lot of people coming in every day. Usually, I cant keep track of how many batches of tea I've brewed, but I usually always remember the faces." It's supposed to be a bank canteen, but no one can stop the stream of students and professors frequenting the shack.
When we approached her, she seemed very hesitant. She served tea to half a dozen or so people and bustled out with her phone pressed to her ear. She returned after talking to her son, content that it was okay to speak to us.
Her tea was as sweet as her personality.

"IIT बहुत अच्छा है, यहाँ के बच्चे भी बहुत अच्छे हैं|"
#hony
#humans
#iitd
(Interviewed by
@maria.1.6
)

📝 MatkaMan
📍 https://www.bspiitd.com/post/matkaman

Prof Next Door
Scholar's Blog

Search
MatkaMan
Pratyush Pandey
Jun 21, 2019
6 min read
I still remember taking up the book 'Franny and Zooey' by JD Salinger as a 17 year old.

A reason why this book resonated with me so much is that it proliferated a strong message - that everything we do is self-serving and self-centred to an extent - even in the most minute ways. Over the years, I have wasted hours trying to convince myself otherwise, but to no avail. This search ended when I met Mr Alag Natarajan, a 60-year-old citizen of Panchsheel Park, Delhi, who is indeed living up to his name, 'alag'. Those of you who might have come across his social service endeavours will know him as 'Matkaman'.
Before his work, let's get to know the man first. Mr Alag Natarajan was a passionate engineer since his childhood. He was capable of fixing an automobile engine before he cleared high school. This passion, clubbed with the inspiration from his father to give something back to the community, served as a drastic turning point later in his life. He joined Ramaiyyah college, Bangalore as a mechanical engineering student, but dropped out to move to London and start his own business. The business took off, and he returned to India nearing his retirement and settled here.
Let's cut to the present day. Mr Alag starts his day at 4 AM in the morning. He fills the tanks of his custom made van with potable water with the help of a pump assembly. He packs eggs and winter clothes and sets off to multiple locations where his 'matkas' are installed. “I started this in a smaller way two years ago by placing a couple of pots on a stand in front of my residence in Panchsheel Park. I noticed a lot of passers-by, especially construction workers and cyclists, going to distant areas for work, stopping to drink water. Also, auto-rickshaw and taxi drivers would not only drink water but also fill their bottles.”
Sensing that it was not enough, Natarajan decided to expand the idea to neighbouring colonies including Green Park, Hauz Khas and Chirag Delhi. But that not only required installing more Matka stands but also the paraphernalia to fill them. Soon, his efforts diversified to giving eggs to feed the poor and giving them warm clothes to help them bear the chilling Delhi winter. As his efforts diversified, so did his van, and he had to import some parts from the USA to sustain his mission.

Today, his van is fitted with a high capacity pump to fill the matkas quickly and efficient, a large plastic tank and a heater generator arrangement to help boil the eggs and feed the poor. Of course, sustaining this effort required a good amount of financial commitment as well, and not backed by any NGO, and set on his journey to try and bring about the change he represents, he is using his life savings for his purpose. He stated on multiple occasions how thankful he is for his supportive wife. “My household help and his wife are my support pillars. That apart, our household help and gardener also assists with much of the work,” he adds.
It has gotten to the point where his efforts have led to him making sacrifices in his own standards of living to sustain and upscale his efforts. "I've had my days of living in the fast lane. I used to be the guy driving the expensive car. Now just last month, me and my wife, we wanted to get us a new car, nothing too fancy. But the thought of spending 15 lakhs to get a new car when it means warmer clothes, nice breakfast to someone poor suffering in Delhi cold was too much. I just couldn't bring myself to do it." He adds how this has engulfed some other aspects of his life as well, and he has simplified his life such that from the clothes he wears to the coffee he drinks, nothing is branded. Which raises the fundamental question - how much does a man need to sustain himself? Something he owes to 'vipassana' for teaching him.
Before he started on this path, a wise person once told him, "The path to righteousness, from the background that you belong to, won't be easy. The people won't understand, and you will expose their hypocrisy." His neighbours objected to his installations of water coolers and benches for the poor, saying it might lead to drunkards and trouble makers coming into the area. They fenced their colony from the footpath connecting it to the main road to keep passerby from coming in. "Why should ordinary people be kept from drinking water due to concerns about trouble makers? Do people who drink not need water?" he grew emotional as he went on. "I cut the fence open with some help. They called the police and got it closed. I opened it again, this time with my own hands.

Thankfully it's been that way for three months."
"People, in their endless pursuit of greed, have lost the ability to touch human lives. Some of my neighbours, who see me filling water in my van in the morning or cutting vegetables to cook for the poor in front of my house never do so much as buy a woollen sock for me to distribute among the poor. The man living next door just bought a brand new Porsche, and he has never done so much as donating a penny for my efforts." he continues - " When people ask me what they can do to help out, the answer is very simple. Give me a dozen eggs. Buy me clothes or vegetables. Go and fill my matkas. Charity begins when one opens one's own pocket for the service of the poor." Stressing that he wished for Panchsheel Park to be an example for future India and how we should treat our poor. "The colony watchmen, from other houses came to thank me once, telling me how they benefited front my coolers — saying how the home owners won't even give them water to drink. I once came across two children outside my house. One was trying to pull a light I had installed on my wall. The other immediately reprimanded him, saying the owner is good, he gives us water and food, so why are you doing this? If I am good to the people, they will never wrong me.
The cynic in me wanted to believe that there was some selfish motif behind this action, but I was quickly proven wrong. Mr Natarajan clarifies early on that he wasn't doing this work for societal validation or even inner satisfaction or happiness. He wanted to work for the sake of working, serve for the sake of serving. His wife took over here and narrated a very simple incident when he saw a person who delivered ice in the scorching Delhi heat on a cycle. He had to hurry so that the ice didn't melt. After observing his routine, Mr Alag called the man, a total stranger, and took him to a bike dealership. Before the man could understand what was happening, he purchased a bike, fitted a basket on it to carry the ice, and handed him the keys. "The guy fell on his feet, but it wouldn't have made any difference if he didn't.

Alag had done his duty, and he would have walked away contended in this fact."
In an effort to know more about the person, and seek answers to some of the questions I had been asking, I decided to interview his close friends and relatives. Some very useful insights came out. For one, Mr alag suffered from cancer while he was in the UK. After fighting it for a few years and almost coming face to face with death, he came back to India and started working with the American Foundation in Varanasi to make the manual rickshaws more efficient. Then he volunteered in Delhi itself in terminal cancer hospitals as a part of an NGO. There were some bodies which no one claimed at that place, so he brought a van to carry these people to the cemetery and give them a proper burial. And this is the same Van he uses, to this day, to help the poor. However, his efforts caught the eye of the NGO leaders, who grew insecure about their position in light of his efforts. Soon it became difficult for him to continue working there, so he decided to leave and start his own independent efforts to make a difference. He doesn't want to be called an NGO, or an organisation of any kind. Its always been him - well, him, his family, and his dog, Snoopy. And the rest is what it is.
To conclude, it's hard to believe people like him exist in today's A-grade colonies, with such pure motivations to serve. People who put others first unconditionally. Another quote by Salinger comes to mind - "Introduce me to the egoless human, and I will be his or her unabashed servant till the end of time." So the next time you are in Panchsheel Park, make sure you pay his house a visit. Any watchman or pedestrian will tell you the way.

You will find the 'matkaman' sitting on his porch, ever ready for tea and amazing conversations, and his dog Snoopy, right by his side, ever ready to play fetch.
(Interviewed by Pratyush Pandey)
Humans of IITD

Technical Clubs
Explore the various technical clubs at IIT Delhi.

DevClub
DevClub
A student-run club focused on developing software solutions for the campus community.

 
iGEM
iGEM
International Genetically Engineered Machine team working on synthetic biology projects.

 
Physics & Astronomy Club
Physics & Astronomy Club (PAC)
Exploring the wonders of physics and astronomy through experiments and observations.

 
Business and Consulting Club
Business and Consulting Club (BnC)
Developing business acumen and consulting skills through case studies and workshops.

 
Aeromodelling Club
Aeromodelling Club
Building and flying model aircraft and learning about aerodynamics principles.

 
Economics Club
Economics Club
Discussing economic theories, policies, and their real-world applications.

 
Algorithms and Computing Club
Algorithms and Computing Club (ANCC)
Enhancing algorithmic problem-solving and competitive programming skills.

 
Aries
Aries
Focusing on electronics, circuits, and embedded systems development.

 
Indian Game Theory Society
Indian Game Theory Society (IGTS)
Studying game theory and its applications in economics, politics, and strategic decision-making.

 
Blockchain Society
Blockchain Society (BlocSoc)
Exploring blockchain technology, cryptocurrencies, and decentralized applications.

 
Robotics Club
Robotics Club
Building and programming robots for various competitions and projects.

 
Hyperloop
Hyperloop
Working on high-speed transportation technology and hyperloop pod design.

 
Axlr8r
Axlr8r Formula Racing
Accelerating student startups and innovation through mentorship and resources.

Name: APL703
Course: APL703
Link to Course website https://bsw.iitd.ac.in/coursepage.php?course=APL703

Introductory Fresher’s Magazine for PG

GENESIS

VOL 3 | 2023-24

B?

P

Board for Student Publications

Greetings!

As you begin your postgraduate journey, you might have newer goals and a
renewed ambition to make your mark. Before you delve into this journey of
unknowns, we at the Board for Student Publications (in short, BSP) would like to
congratulate you on making it here. Adapting to this new environment at IITD,
newer people, processes and culture can be a challenging process, and you
would require all the help you can get. Fikar not! BSP is here to serve as a helpful
resource for your times ahead.

BSP is one of the seven boards at IIT Delhi. Over the past many years, we have
been the voice of IIT Delhi and its residents and we strive to maintain the legacy.
At IITD, you may think of focusing more on the academics and possible
prospects, but you might miss out on the vibrant life on our campus. Therefore,
through our PG fresher's magazine, Genesis, we bring to you IIT Delhi through
the eyes of a team of about 60-odd writers and designers. Inside the magazine,
you will find unlimited fundaes, an abundance of helpful information, and a
plethora of fun facts about accommodation, hostels, clubs, bodies, etc. Let us
take you on a virtual tour of your newest destination, IIT Delhi.

We hope you have as amazing a time reading Genesis as we had creating it. We
hope to see you soon at the campus, chilling in Biotech Lawns, crunching
delicacies at night messes, or running from one lecture to another at LHC.

Adios Amigos!
Let the Genesis begin!

Best Wishes,
Chief Editor - Harshit Garg

Special Thanks

Prof.

Genesis 2024 | 03

 

UNDERSTANDING LIFE AT ITD
ABSTRACT

Here we go again! Another college, another degree! Two years or five! Yeah it's gonna
be a wild ride so allow us to assist you with our research.

Here is a cheat sheet on all
things IITD! Ranging from fellowships to where to live, we bring you a detailed
analysis of how to get the best out of your journey with IIT.

LITERATURE REVIEW

This is the section where we have reviewed the scenario relating to stipends, attendance
policies and accommodations.

Fellowships

Coming to those brave hearts who spend a significant chunk of their life at the lab,
PhD Community: This grovp of students receives 37000 INR for the first two years
followed by 42000 INR for the next three. (After which if you wish to extend, you
will be asked to fund for yourself). They also get an additional HRA ( House Rent
Allowance ) which is 27% of the stipend. For their research purposes, students also
receive a certain amount of contingency fund. Details regarding this should be
obtained from immediate seniors. Stipend for Phd students will stop if they get less
than 7.5 CGPA.

Those joining as an MSR/MTech/MSc student will receive 12400 INR (you might
not receive this exact amount if your first semester starts after the first of the
month). This community does not receive any HRA or contingency.

Stipend also stops if the student scores below 7 CGPA, for that particular semester.
Remember to mark your scholarship attendance within the first 20 days of every
month, on the e-academics portal.

Accommodation

In a new city, the biggest hassle is to find a place which comes closest to home. Here
is a preview of what you might face once you arrive on campus.

Off-Campus Living-

Since most of the PG students cannot get a hostel in their first year, we talked to
senior students about how they have managed the situation. There are numerous
coaching hubs next to the campus such as Jia sarai, Katwaria sarai and Ber sarai have
paying guest accommodations.

Female candidates-

IITD does try its best and usually all incoming female candidates are able to get a
spot in one of the hostels. The safest and most preferred accommodation choice for
females was found to be inside the campus.

Genesis 2024 | 04

Off- Campus vs On- Campus-

Katwaria sarai, Jia sarai and Adchini are easily accessible through campus
gates(you might find it difficult to locate these at first but don't worry these will
soon become your go-to spots!).

On the other hand Pancheel and Monirka are a bit
away from campus and require travel arrangements to be factored into your cost of
living. This could be beneficial for those who prefer to leave the campus life away
from home. pore Adchini

CED
Katwaria
Sarai f \ moe Monirka OQ 4k-&k @ 3k-8k
© 6k-12k © 5k-10k
Z @  5k-9k
NA ON OOOO Panchsheel
Jia Sarai

Figure: Cost comparison amongst off-campus accommodations.
(Locations sorted as per closest proximity to campus starting from Jia Serai)
Note that prices may vary due to factors such as high demand, size and amenities
included, and exposure to sunlight among others.

Some issves highlighted by residents:
- Jia sarai + Katwaria sarai those closer to campus are relatively full of students
oreparing for various exams and this can sometimes make the places feel
cramped with people.
* Adchini: This is where Adchini and Panchseel gain points for relatively peaceful
localities even though a bit farther away from campus.

On-campus living would require you to pay for compulsory mess services which
vsvally amount to approx. 40000 INR apart from the 13250 INR for seat rent.
Remember that this is an addition to the tuition fees. Some students prefer this
easy access to meals as their work schedole doesn't permit them the leisure of
cooking every meal. Point to note that IIT Delhi also offers apartment space to Phd
students who have a family living with them.

RESULT & DISCUSSION

Students might find it difficult at first to find and decide on the best place to live or to
choose between living on campus or outside. However, you will definitely find beavty in
this chaos as there is something for everyone in all of the options listed above. On-
campus living is extremely beneficial for female candidates and for those busy bees
working till late hours. Whereas those hoping to create a home away from home also
have a myriad of options.

So dont take stress about this as you will most probably find
your best match.

05 | Genesis 2024

PEOPLE YOU

Whether you have come to IIT fresh out of your bachelor's, or you're taking a break from the corporate life to
bring laurels to yourself and IIT, there are some people you are sure to encounter! These people will shape how
bad or good your experience you'll be at the institute, so here's a primer so you can be prepared

G

> The people IITD employees!

   

application for travel approved, you're sure to encounter
them in your postgraduate life at IITD. Equipped with a
strong mindset of ‘humare paas time nahi hai’, they are
the category that will take 4 business days to login and
just approve your request on E-academics (at max 7
mouse clicks). Their behavior will not be a surprise for
the corporate returnees, but for the BTech grads who
want to machau in their masters, your life won't be eas
as their lunch and tea breaks are non-negotiable.
PS. Your persistence will ultimately win so hang
in there!

 
     
   
     
       
     
    
    
       
       
    
 
 
 
     
 
 
    
 
   

 
  
  

 
 

The professors:
Head, SRC Members,
and course coordinators
During your time at IITD, you will encounter a variety of
professors, who will either be your Head of department or or
be teaching you courses. If you feel that you have seen lots of
professors and are sorta used to them, you are bound to find
a new variety that will surprise you. For the PhD
students, please fear your SRC members or
their questions and remarks during you
presentations will be your
demise.

  

  

The Accounts/CSC staff

In comparison to the Academic
Section, the Accounts and CSC
staff will be much more helpful
and so your visit to them won't be
too much of a headache.

officers could either be super helpful or take days to
forward your application or get it the

The Supervisor

Whether you're here for MSc, or MPP, or PhD, you
will have to undertake at least 6 months of research
or project work under your ‘supervisor, Please choose
them carefully, and if you have no choice in choosing
them, keep your relations cordial. You'll have to face
them with results and outcomes that are suboptimal
but remember, you got this! The best
advice we have: take their criticisms
about the project/research but don't
pay heed to the statements they

make about you!

   
      

The Guardians of the IITD
galaxy

Deputed at multiple places across the campus,
these blue uniform-donning security guards

at IITD will greet you wherever you go, especially
at the LHC entrance where they won't let you

in without an ID card. Depending on the time
and place, you may end up making very
good friends of them or you may be the
victim of their stern
voice.

  

Genesis 2024 | 06

2 VN INEIL IMIENE TT

> The people you'll spend more time with!

 

 
  
   
   
 
   
   
   
   
   
   
   
   
  

  

BTech Students
Given that TA-ing is mandatory for all fellowship
students, you will have your share of interactions with the
BTech students on the campus. While some of them may be
genuinely curious about what you teach, others just want to
finish and leave as soon as possible. Their seemingly
reckless behaviour may irk you at times but remember to be
patient with them. They are enrolled in an
average of 7 courses and therefore, are

mostly stressed about the never-ending
assignments and exams (which you
may be too during your
first semester).

 
 

  

> Lab Members

Once you have finished your coursework, you will spend a large amount of your time working in the
lab with people you may end up being the closest to or make enemies out of. Here are some kinds
you will encounter

   
     
 
 
     
 
    
 
    
   
    
 
 
     

The Lab Organization freak

The ‘organization freak’ of your lab will always be
found tidying up desks and cleaning lab
equipment. Sometimes, their obsession with

cleanliness may lead them to throw away ®
important samples and create unwanted chaos. &@
But, there will be days you'll be thankful for their @ @
existence.

@

 

The ‘Always-out-of-money’

  

Fresh out of BTech, even the measly
MTech/MSR stipend can feel like a lot,
but always being out of money is a state
that you may find yourself in. Ashamed
of asking parents for money, the
struggle to manage money may
feel very real. But, you got this!

07 | Genesis 2024 ©

AS YOU START, IT MAY ALL FEEL OVERWHELMING DUE TO THE CONSTANT JUGGLING BETWEEN
KEEPING UP WITH COURSES & PROJECTS AND TAKING ADEQUATE BREAKS. TO ADD TO IT, THE
CONSTANT INFLUX OF EMAILS, AND SEMINAR REMINDERS WHILE YOU’/RE RUNNING FROM PILLAR
TO POST TO LAND A JOB AFTER GRADUATION MAY NOT BE VERY HELPFUL EITHER. TO PREPARE
FOR YOUR JOURNEY AT IITD, WE HAVE SUMMARIZED THE LINGO YOU'LL HEAR EVERYDAY AND
THE SEASONS YOU WILL HAVE TO BRAVE.

CASES.

THE PHASE OF DESPAIR

DESPITE ALL YOUR EFFORTS, YOU MAY HAVE TO SEE THE
PHASE OF DESPAIR WHEN YOUR PROJECT OR RESEARCH
WILL BARELY MOVE FORWARD. IN SUCH TIMES, YOU NEED
TO PERSEVERE AND YOU'LL COME OUT STRONG.

 

THE SEASON OF PRESENTATIONS

THE SEMESTER-END WILL NOT ONLY RELIEVE YOU
OF YOUR TEACHING DUTIES BUT ALSO BRING FORTH
THE SEASON OF PRESENTATIONS. THIS SEASON
WILL SEE YOU CRYING OVER THE SLIDES YOU HAVE
PUT YOUR SOUL AND HEART INTO. BUT, WORRY NOT,
FOR THIS SEASON WILL PASS NOT LONGER AFTER

SAY GOODBYES. GOODBYES ARE HARD, SO WE'LL LET YOU

EXPLANATIONS FROM THE BOARD)

BRCA CLUBS

 

7X TECH CLUB

 

If you’re one of those who crave responsibility and do not shy away from it, you will have the chance
to make a meaningful contribution in various verticals when Rendezvous and Tryst roll around.

For
the uninitiated (in other words, those living under a rock), Rendezvous and Tryst are the two biggest
fests organized in IIT Delhi. They are completely organized by students, meaning that being part of
the organizing team will give you priceless insights into event and people management.

12 | Genesis 2024

 

   

   

   

  

 

bbe

This will be the first website you access
using the credentials received in the
welcome email from IITD. Remember the
password for this (it's different from your
Kerberos credentials), as all the admission
forms are available on this website. All the
fees and mess dues are to be paid here;
keep checking this regularly to avoid paying
late fines.

Arguably the most helpful website, BSW's
website is the most valuable resource panel
for all your first-year courses. You'll find past
year tutorial sheets and solutions, old majors
and minors as part of their freshie resources
tab. In addition, you'll find Careers and
Placements information and guides to set up
things like your email and internet. This is the
one-stop solution for all your ‘Getting
Started’ and ‘One day before exam’ woes. Be
sure to go through this site thoroughly!

This is the heart of all the websites at IIT D;
every website at IIT D can be accessed here,
the "For Students” section being the most
important. It also connects you to all the
departmental websites. Wanna know the
semester schedule? How about checking on
updates on events and research happening
at IITD? The home website gives you all this
information and more. Do spend time
exploring this absolute gem of a website!

Gradescope:

Gradescope is the website for MTL and COL
evaluations; you will scan your answer
sheets, see your evaluated scripts and
submit scores of regrade requests here. The
evaluation completion mail usually makes
you skip a beat if you haven't blasted the
test to shreds.

Be careful not to submit
"frivolous" regrade requests, as you can lose
marks.

Moodle:

Moodle is an online learning system that
many instructors use to upload notes, course
slides, homework and (in some dire cases)
quizzes. Some professors may also utilise the
platform to make announcements such as
class schedules or course policies. Thus,
always be on the lookout for updates on this
space! On opening the IITD Moodle page,
youre welcomed with a deceptively simple
captcha system which will permanently have
you questioning your ability to do questions
like ‘69-83' to verify you're human:
downloading an auto-captcha may end up
saving a lot of your time (and mental sanity)!

   

 

x

Webmail. iitd.ac.in:

This website will likely be the most visited site

in your browser after joining IIT. The IITD
webmail is the official communication
channel at IIT and connects you with fellow
students, professors and staff. It can be
accessed using your Kerberos ID (which you /\
will receive using Scorner). All updates about
quizzes, extra classes, orientations, webinars, /\
application deadlines, tutorials and, of course,

BSP’s monthly TLDR newsletter about campus /\
happenings are sent via Webmail. Remember

to organise your Webmail and be updated, or A
you will find yourself missing quizzes!

NSN

You type in your username and password with
a pounding heart and shaking hands. As the
page unfolds, there are the grades you've
been working hard towards all year. This portal
does more than record your grades; it also
keeps tabs on your co-curricular and fee
records. It will also be where you can find
Courses Of Study and essential updates.
Remember to get yourself VPN access from
the CSC if you want to access Moodle or
Eacads while not on campus. Scholarship
attendance has to be marked on Eacads.

moves smooth, courtesy of a rich quizzing and
dance culture. If that isn’t enough attention, how
about a unique two-party politics system?

S @ COUNCILS

ecause we do more than just study!

—I//l= STUDENT AFFAIRS COUNCIL

The Student Affairs Council is the apex student body of IIT Delhi and oversees
all non-academic student affairs on campus. It is responsible for maintaining
the student welfare, ensuring a conducive and healthy environment for the
holistic development of students. It recognises five boards - BSW, BSP, BSA,
Le BRCA, and BHM, each of which is responsible for a different facet of student
life. SAC aspires to be a transparent body and welcomes regular feedback and
suggestions from students. Any student may reach out to SAC via their
respective hostel representatives. The SAC website also furnishes minutes of
the meetings, new policies, and other information pertaining to student
Uy welfare and representation.

=

   

CO-CURRICULAR AND ACADEMIC INTERACTION COUNCIL

The council serves as a governing body over technical and academic
organisations while also overseeing a myriad of technical clubs and all
departmental societies. Its primary function revolves around managing and
regulating these entities. Furthermore, the council plays a pivotal role in
fostering a healthy and comprehensive dialogue between students and
professors, creating an environment conducive to intellectual exchange. By
redressing academic grievances, the council maintains a positive academic
space year-round, enabling students to unleash their full potential.
Additionally, the council organises Tryst, one of North India’s largest technical
fests. This event showcases technical prowess and serves as a platform for
innovation and the recognition of individuals’ talents.

BRCA is where the pursuit of knowledge harmoniously intertwines with the
spirit of recreation and creativity.

Beyond the corridors of academia, IIT Delhi
offers a plethora of engaging activities.to enthral your spirits. It oversees the
functioning of the eleven cultural.clubs, each of which offers a unique avenue
for self-expression and personal growth. Thanks to them, exhilarating
competitions, awe-inspiring workshops, and collaborative events can be
executed. Be on the lookout for BRCA Freshers’ Night, where they proudly
introduce themselves and awaken the dormant artist in you. And don't you dare
miss out on Rendezvous, one of the most-awaited cultural college fests, which
is organised by BRCA.

 

16 | Genesis 2024

BOARD FOR SPORTS ACTIVITIES

IIT Delhi has a thriving sporting culture thanks to the efforts of the Board for
Sports Activities or BSA. This is the overarching board managing, regulating,
and conducting various sporting events throughout the year. It conducts trials
for 13 different sports, maintains equipment, and caters to the sportspeople on
campus! The board organises an annual sports fest - Sportech which sees
active participation from various institutes. Moreover, the much-revered inter-
hostel sports championship - General Championship or GC is conducted by
BSA. The board is sustained by a number of executives, coordinators, vice-
captains, and captains at multiple levels.

YY

 

BOARD FOR STUDENT PUBLICATIONS

Yup! That's us — the official student-run digital and print media body of IIT Delhi.
We work endlessly so that you are updated with the latest happenings on
campus, from cultural events to technical breakthroughs. We publish a series of
magazines: Inception (for the overwhelmed fresher), Elemental (for the
technologically curious), and Muse (for the creative escapist). We are
responsible for newsletters that analyse problems faced at campus with a
down-to-earth approach. On the lighter side, we explore the non-academic side
of professors, collect fundae from machau seniors.and efficiently disseminate
them to the student community. Dont miss out on Gazettale, the annual
magazine making competition, and Literati - the annual literary fest for the lover
of language and literature among you!

  
   

ZA),

BOARD FOR STUDENT WELFARE

BSW is responsible for facilitating the welfare of the students on campus. The
board has two divisions: operations and mentorship.

It has a number of
effective programs such as language mentorship (for students who wish to
hone their English language), acad mentorship (for help in first-year courses by
seniors), and the mentorship program (for incoming freshers). Campus tours
and events like Delhi Darshan are also organised by BSW to make for pleasant
beginnings for freshers! Watch out for internship and placement fundae,
seminars, and last-minute revision sessions to make yout life a little easier. BSW
also takes care of sustained student health by spreading awareness about
mental health and counselling platforms like SCS, YourDost, etc. BSW
representatives are among the first seniors you will interact with on campus.

 

Zi

BOARD FOR HOSTEL MANAGEMENT

BHM is the only board that touches the life of every student every single day!
They are responsible for operating and maintaining the hostel messes and other
amenities for students around the campus. You can reach out to your BHM
representative to complain (read: rant) about food quality or leaking taps. BHM
is maintained by a maintenance and mess secretary at the hostel-level who
releases anew mess menu roughly each month. They also work closely with the
administration to bring you new facilities such as the newly opened Udaigiri
night mess! So, count on BHM. to: deliver quick and effective solutions to your
boarding and gastronomical problems on campus!

 

Genesis 2024 | 17

 

Design Club

Welcome to the Design Club at IIT Delhi! In just a year, we've become a leading club on campus,
promoting design thinking, user experience, and aesthetics. This year, we're thrilled to launch
Delineate, our design society for participating in inter-college competitions. Last year, we
achieved an astonishing first place at the INTER IIT cultural meet in design. At the Design Club,
we collaborate on aesthetic and practical solutions to problems. It's a space for experimentation,
where we explore ideas and learn from mistakes. We enjoy discussing our thoughts on bad
designs (looking at you, Comic Sans!). Whether you're curious about design or want to connect
with like-minded individuals, join us in fostering innovation and a passion for design.

| rae
FACC

Unleash your creativity with the Fine Arts and Crafts Club! We're not just a group of artists; we're
acommunity that celebrates the freedom of self-expression. Join us and dive into a world where
imagination knows no limits.

Whether you're a seasoned painter or a complete beginner, we've
got you covered. From sketching to painting with charcoal, acrylics, and oils, we offer a range of
mediums to explore. Let your inner artist shine and be part of our vibrant creative journey. "Art is
the journey where mistakes become masterpieces and shadows reveal hidden brilliance."
Welcome to FACC, where art comes to life...

La [| | Tt
Quizzing Club

QC is the one-stop shop for all the curious folks who like seemingly random but amazing facts,
or "fundas" as we like to call them, covering a variety of genres like sci-tech, entertainment,
business, sports, history, and so on. We are a tightly-knit community, united by the pleasure we
derive from cracking a funda. The wide variety of questions ensures that everyone's knowledge,
however outlandish, is respected. Moreover, it's not all “if-you-know-you-know”; most of the
questions are curated by our quizmasters so that you can logically arrive at the answer too. So,
put on your thinking caps and join us on this never-ending quest of acquiring knowledge!

AEE
Literary Club

Who do we have here - A relentless reader, a fanatical film enthusiast, a wizard at word games, a
(w)remarkable writer, a passionate poet - or an overlap of them all? Rest assured, the Literary
Club has a little bit to offer for everyone. And by little bit we mean Book Discussions, Review
Sessions, Excursions, Word Games, Lit Quizzes, Cryptic Crosswords, Slam Poetry, Creative
Writing, Just-A-Minute Comps and a lot more. We are also the wardens of the LitClub Library -
the only non-academic book collection in IIT Delhi. And do not worry, you do not have to be an
expert to call LitClub your home. A community of like minded enthusiasts await you, inspired by
their love of everything creative and fun that can be put into words.

| |
Photography and Films Club

Welcome to the captivating world of the Photography and Films Club (PFC)! Get ready to
embark on a journey through the realms of visual storytelling. Our Society and Videography
Society creates a vibrant community of creatives like yourself. Prepare to be amazed by the
Freshers League, where the brightest stars of our club showcase their talents.

From photowalks
that capture the essence of the world to intercollege competitions that ignite friendly rivalries,
we offer a plethora of opportunities to unleash your creativity. Our team of mentors will guide and
inspire you, ensuring that your skills flourish and your visions come to life. Welcome to PFC,
where the power of photography and filmmaking is unleashed upon a canvas of possibilities!

Music Club

The Music Club, IIT Delhi organises various events throughout the year to foster the culture of
Music among the community of IIT Delhi. Its first event of the year is Euphony, the highly
anticipated open mic event which unfolds as a remarkable showcase of raw talent and
boundless enthusiasm. It provides an opportunity to the freshers to showcase their musical
genius to an appreciative audience. It helps them to overcome their stage fear and make bonds
with like-minded people.

Euphony sets the stage for a flourishing musical journey throughout
the year for freshers.

BY ez lanre)

The Dramatics Club at IIT Delhi opens the doors to a captivating world of drama where you can
shine through acting, writing, directing, and production.

Within Ankahi, our dramatics society,
two teams thrive: the Stage Team, devoted to theaters and cinemas, and the Street Team,
showcasing street drama and nukkad natak. Our diverse range of events and competitions,
from the Freshers Monoact to inter-hostel competitions, offer exclusive stages to discover
hidden talents. Alongside workshops and intra-college events, both teams venture into
intercollege events, providing exposure. Experienced seniors from the world of cinema will
guide and mentor you, honing your skills and nurturing your personality through dramatics. Join
us on this path of self-discovery, where you unfold your potential.

(SEN YA yA
Debating Club

Humans are inherently opinionated creatures. But to be able to delve deep into your belief
systems and deconstruct them is what is truly magical. If you've ever found yourself falling down
the rabbit hole of rhetorics or questioning axiomatic truths, DebSoc is the place to be! They offer
you the chance to learn how to construct arguments effectively and articulate them
convincingly. It's asociety where everyone starts from scratch and leaves with the confidence to
question fundamental ideas and stand their ground. Not only do they debate on various social,
political, and philosophical ideas, but they also stay up late at the night mess, having post-debate
conversations and much more. From 3 days long debate tournaments, legendary parties, and
probably the most welcoming seniors you'll ever find, they have it all!

a
Spic Macay

Are you a soul eager to explore the wonders of Indian classical music, dance, and culture? Look
no further than SPIC MACAY (Society for the Promotion of Indian Classical Music And Culture
Amongst Youth). It's an incredible platform designed just for you! SPIC MACAY embraces the
energy and interests of young people, introducing them to the world of ancient art forms. From
classical concerts to dance performances and interactive workshops, SPIC MACAY offers a
gateway to discover the magic of India's heritage. Imagine immersing yourself in the enchanting
rhythms, movements, and cadences that have transcended time. Join the SPIC MACAY family,
connect with like-minded individuals, and embark on a journey where tradition and innovation
intertwine!

| | |
Dance Club

If you're someone who wants to explore dance, have fun and create memories for a lifetime, the
Dance Club is the place to be.

The Club is known for its glamorous events, captivating
performances and exciting workshops. Our flagship event, Group Dance is a night where every
hostel sends out its best and performs. The fresher’s Offbeat sets the stage for the future
dancers. Our dance societies, VDefyn and Ensemble have earned great recognition over the
years, competing at the regional and national levels. The club creates a welcoming environment
where students from all backgrounds and dance levels can feel comfortable expressing
themselves. Whether you're a seasoned dancer or just starting, you'll find a community that
celebrates individuality and fosters growth.

with a dynamic team! Typically starting in the second semester, the recruitment process entails a series of

assignments and hands-on learning sessions, followed by an interview.

 

AXLRSR Formula Racing

 

Are you a gearhead who has an affinity for engineering and a thirst for competition? Does the idea
of envisioning something, building from scratch, and competing on a worldwide platform sound
enticing to you? Then, AXLR8R Formula Racing(AFR) might be the calling for you!

They design, build and test Single-seat Formula-style Electric race cars to compete in Formula
Student competitions on national and international platforms. The club stands by its motto of
#ThelrackThatHasloBeWon and aims to build a family of enthusiastic students who share a
common passion for automobiles and engineering.

The work undertaken lies at the intersection of fields like mechanical, electrical, and management. It
incorporates team building, leadership, time management, and communication skills in its members.
It boasts a rich alumni network to support its endeavours and has many leading companies as
sponsors. The recruitment process includes workshops, mini-projects, and interviews which occur
close to the end of the first year.

The club is based out of the dedicated Innovation Centre in the

 

If IITD's vibrant startup culture is what drew you here, and you too aspire to.start.your own
unicorn, eDC is the place for you! The IIT Delhi's Entrepreneurship. Development. Cell. (eDC)
fosters an entrepreneurial attitude among, the student. body. through various. activities like
guest lectures, startup showcases, and enjoyable workshops.

One of the events for first-year students is Muskeeters, where you can gain hands-on
experience in building a startup from scratch. In this event, you'll form a team and work with
mentors to develop your startup idea. Don't miss the annual BECON; India's biggest
entrepreneurship fest spanning three days.

BECON brings together students and startup enthusiasts from colleges all over India, offering
a schedule packed with skill-based workshops, inspiring talks from Successful entrepreneurs,
and thrilling competitions to sharpen and showcase your skills. Fhe flagship event, Shark
Tank, invites startups from all over India to pitch in front of investors and secure funding and
prizes. You can pick up important management skills, catch a glimpse of the bustling world-of
CEOs and VCs, and gain extensive knowledge of the entrepreneurial process)

Physics and Astronomy Club

In the vast expanse of the cosmos, where stars ignite and celestial bodies dance in harmony,
there exists a club that unites passionate minds, curious souls, and aspiring: scientists. PAC
serves as a vibrant platform for students with a keen interest in physics and astronomy to come
together, collaborate, and explore the realms of these captivating disciplines.

 
 
 
 
  
  

With a focus on both theoretical knowledge and practical application, PAC organizes a
myriad of events and workshops throughout the academic year, aimed at nurturing the
» skills and passion of its members.Workshops cover various topics, including quantum
$“/ —mechanies, astrophysicsecosmology, rocketry and advanced researchmethodologies.

sessions take place in the biotech lawn and lectures and discussions are held at

the LHC. Recruitment includés a form followed by an interview, typically =
unfolding at the end of the first year.

Infinity Hyperloop Club

Do you envision a future where high-speed travel inside a vacuum-sealed pod-becomes a reality? Are you
someone who dreams about being part of the technological revolution.in-transport? If yes, then Infinity Hyperloop
is the club for you!

   

This dedicated team has been developing hyperloop technology which was first introduced by Elon Musk. Its
mission is to create a fully functioning hyperloop pod prototype. It has already developed a fully functioning Linear <—z
Induction Motor (LIM), making it one of the earliest clubs to achieve this significant milestone. It researches =
existing information, creates its own technologies, and participates in many national and _ international
competitions like the European Hyperloop Week, which makes learning yet more fun. The club is driven by an
unwavering zeal to transform this mode of transportation into a reality not only in India but also across the world. If
you wish to contribute to the future of transportation, you can join any of the sub-departments and be a part of
this exciting and innovative project. The recruitment process typically happens during the summer break, so be on
the lookout for it. You can also visit the RNI park on campus to see the cool work environment.

Aeromodelling Club

Welcome aboard, future aviation enthusiasts! Get ready to embark on an exhilarating journey into the
world of the Aeromodelling Club. Here, your imagination will soar, your dreams will take flight, and you'll be
part of a fantastic community of talented individuals. From crafting drones and planes to creating avionics
systems, the interdisciplinary club provides a dynamic platform for learning and innovation.

Under the
mentorship of experienced seniors, you'll dive into the intricacies of aircraft design, discover the secrets of
aerodynamics, and learn the software needed to simulate their functioning.

However, it's not all technicalities and calculations! The club ventures into exciting projects like the
renowned D&L 1234, a carbon fibre-based VTOL, etc. Along the way, you'll develop essential soft skills
like event management and team coordination, ensuring you're a well-rounded aviator. The recruitment
process, involving a short test and an interview, seeks out passionate aviators ready to spread their wings

and fly high!

Economics Club

Step into the captivating world of the Economics Club at IIT Delhi, where economics, finance, and game theory intertwine
like the complex plot twists of a best-selling novel. Join us on our exhilarating journey through Dalal Street, where you'll learn
to navigate the ups and downs of the financial landscape. Engage in thrilling events like Bluffs & Bargains, where strategic
moves are akin to a high-stakes game of chess.

  

Our workshops, like WnDs, are your magical portals to unravel the secrets of economic wizardry.

Prepare to be
awestruck as luminaries like Raghuram Rajan grace our stage, sharing wisdom akin to a master storyteller.
Gain an unrivalled understanding of the intricate dance between government functionality and public policies,
like deciphering the enigmatic codes of a classic mystery novel. Freshers, embark on this extraordinary
adventure, where the pages of economics come alive with vibrant hues of creativity and innovation. Join the
Economics Club and script your own tale of economic brilliance! Recruitment starts at the start of the 2nd year
consisting of a small questionnaire followed by an interview.

MENTAL HEALTH

The experience of stepping into a completely new world of college
might overwhelm you. As you walk past the doors of your dream
institute, you will be left bewitched by its beauty! The beauty of the
opportunities it throws at you, the new experiences it brings your
way, and the lifelong friends that you make here. But with all the fun
and merry come a few challenges. You might feel lost at times, you
would perhaps feel out of place, or that you are unable to cope with
life and live up to your own expectations. How do we know that?
Because we all have been through the same struggles. Every soul on
campus goes through this rough patch once and many go through it
multiple times. However, what you should know is that this is
completely normal. You may not realize this, but every person around
you is as perplexed as yourself. We're all trying to figure out our lives
because this is what a transition looks like.

 

 

 

Here are some of the difficulties you might experience and what you should do to
battle them:

1. Feeling Out of Place

In an institute where the top minds of the country are brought together, you are bound to feel
intimidated at some point. Seeing everyone excel in something or the other might compel you to
doubt your capabilities. But what you need to remember is that you are among those top brains too!
You've made it here after immense hard work and dedication. You too deserve to be here for you have
come a long way and you shouldn't let anybody bring your self-confidence and faith down!

2. Home-sickness/ Isolation

Not many of us had lived away from our families and friends until this point in time. It is very natural
for you to miss your loved ones and cry for their company. You might as well have a hard time
struggling to make friends but never forget that this phase will pass real quick. You will meet some
amazing people here who will always be on your side and will make your journey memorable. The only
catch here is that this takes time. So just hold on to it until you find your group, just like we all did!

3.

Disappointment
It is quite normal for you to feel dejected when things don’t turn out your way, when you don’t score
as per your expectations, when you fail to make it to your desired clubs, or when the hostel hygiene
gives you nightmares. In times like these, all that you have to remember is that everyone, just like
you, is sailing in the same boat and is facing all these issues. You are not alone and you must embrace
the change with open arms.

In addition to the above-mentioned assurances that you should
think about whenever you find yourself facing a mental block,
IIT Delhi too has got your back. It has some ways planned out
for you that will help you combat these situations. This includes
the BSW Curated Content consisting of fun-filled playlists,
movies, videos, etc. which can be accessed by scanning the QR
code; the counselors present on campus who you can approach
by simply dropping them an email or even ringing up their
phones in case of emergency. Moreover, feel free to reach out
to your mentors for help because they too had experienced all
this and are very well aware of how to overcome such
situations.

 

24 | Genesis 2024

 

Rendezvous, the annual fest at IIT Delhi, is an unparalleled experience that words
cannot accurately capture. It surpasses expectations year after year, leaving attendees
with unforgettable memories. This four-day extravaganza offers a wide range of events
in dance, drama, debate, photography, music, literature, and more, catering to diverse
interests. The campus is adorned with marvelous decorations, creating a vibrant
atmosphere. The highlight of Rendezvous is the Pronites, featuring extravagant
concerts and awe-inspiring performances by renowned artists like Benny Dayal and
Sunidhi Chauhan. With a legacy of greatness, RDV23 promises tobe even bigger and
better, drawing youth from all over the country. It's an event you simply cannot miss.

  

LI ee Gh

Get ready to have your mind blasted into the digitarstratoSphere, at Tryst, the epic three-day tech-
fest of IITD organized by CAIC! It's like.a Wild rollercoaster side, for Tech junkies, where you'll learn,
innovate, and explore more nerdy goodness than you-can €odeé in a lifetime.

We've got competitions

Join forces with over 100 NGOs and immerse yourself in enthralling opportunities alongside

their work. And that's not all! Prepare to be awestruck by Ingenious Geeks 2.0, where the brilliance
of science meets the creativity of school kids. Prepare yourself for a delightful and astonishing
experience with Kaizen!

The GC (General Championship) culture at IIT is more than just a spirited tradition am
—it's a competitive arena where students showcase their talents and embrace

challenges with determination.

In the realm of GC, students form alliances, representing their hostels with pride.

They engage in a friendly clash of talents across various domains, pushing their

limits to achieve victory. It's a vibrant atmosphere where students strive to excel

and grow.

The GC culture at IIT celebrates the underdogs who rise to the occasion, inspiring

their peers with their resilience and achievements. During the GC season, the

campus buzzes with energy and ambition as students refine their skills and

pursue excellence.

Beyond the battles and rivalries, the GC culture at IIT fosters camaraderie and

friendship. It teaches students that success is earned through hard work and

dedication, and setbacks are met with resilience, serving as stepping stones

towards future triumphs.

The GC culture at IIT is a reminder that success encompasses not only y

Mittal Sports Complex: enjoy state-oF-

the-art facilities for indoor sports, including Squash,

IIT Delhi. Get ready for thrilling indoor sports action!

 

Squash at IIT Delhi: Equip yourself with a racket, step onto the court, and embrace the
captivating world of squash at SAC and the Mittal. Get ready for intense rallies and a
thrilling squash experience!

Tennis at IIT Delhi: Serve up a smashing tennis experience on meticulously 8 maintained
courts - both clay and hard, with coaching facilities for all skill levels. Grab a racket, rally
with fellow tennis enthusiasts, and dominate the court!

Badminton at IIT Delhi: Experience thrilling rallies and powerful smashes on well-
maintained courts at SAC and Mittal, surrounded by skilled players and a vibrant
badminton community. Grab a racket and unleash your badminton skills!

Football at IIT Delhi: Score goals on a magnificent football ground located in the heart of
the campus, and unleash your passion for the game in a thrilling environment. Lace up your
shoes and be a football superstar!

Volleyball at IIT Delhi: Set, spike, and serve your way to victory on practice courts including
a sandy volleyball court. With coaching and summer camps, become a volleyball legend and
feel the thrill of the game!

Cricket at IIT Delhi: Join the cricketing glory with intense matches on a world-class pitch,
guided by dedicated coaches and summer camps, and experience the camaraderie of a
passionate community. Step onto the field and become a cricket champion!

Weightlifting at IIT Delhi: Power up at well-equipped gyms in SAC and each hostel, join
the competitive buzz, and witness your strength developing firsthand. Prepare to lift,
challenge your limits, and become a weightlifting powerhouse!

Chess at IIT Delhi: Unleash your intellectual prowess in weekly tournaments, learn from pro
players and coaches, and indulge in the addictive thrill of its vibrant community. It's time to
make your moves and master the 64 squares!

Swimming at IIT Delhi: Dive into excellence with well-maintained pools at SAC, qualified
coaches, and a focus on physical fitness and mental well-being.

Get ready to make a splash
and unleash your swimming skills - but beware of Delhi's winter season when the pools are
shut.

28 | Genesis 2024

BEING

[No, not the one associated with the famous Bollywood Actor]

Your life at IIT Delhi is much more than academics. Between leveraging yourself to greater heights,
and balancing extracurriculars with acads, look around and try to be human. You will always be
proud of the impact you've caused and the ecosystem you've helped build. These are a few of IIT Del-
hi's offerings for you to grow into a better individual.

National Service Scheme-

NSS IIT Delhi is the IIT Delhi chapter of the National Service Scheme, institutionalized under
the Ministry of Youth Affairs & Sports Govt. of India. Our sole aim is to motivate students at
IITD to indulge in nation-building activities through various events and projects which are
aimed towards the benefit of people in and around IIT Delhi. NSS conducts periodical
collection drives as well. This is a very impact-oriented and welfare-driven organisation. You
will meet some of the kindest seniors and Professors here. NSS hosts an annual fest ‘Kaizen’,
which celebrates social endeavors and personalities pan India.

Enactus-

A global socio-entrepreneurial organisation, Enactus is the best of both worlds. (Ever imagined
Scrooge McDuck helping set out village infrastructure? Time to get onto that Midjourney API!)
Enactus IIT Delhi is the right place to learn firsthand about business and starting up. Their
projects are focused on creating an equitable world, while simultaneously utilising tools like
design thinking, unit economics, distribution laws, business plans, et cetera.

Enactus has a very relaxed hierarchy where-in you call your seniors by their name. It is
subdivided into various Projects and Divisions like- Jhabua, Daksha, PlanetLabs, Funding and
Finance, Events and Outreach.

P.S- These are a bunch of very hardworking and tight-knit folk. Their recruitment process, akin to that of BSP is
extremely exhaustive and fun!

P.P.S.- Answer any and all questions in their orientation, you'll be flooded with chocolates. :)

Blood Connect-

An NGO started right in the halls of IIT Delhi, this organisation has helped save close to 4 lakh
lives since its inception in 2010.

India is a blood-deficient nation, which, however, can be
mitigated to a large extent by voluntary blood donation. This is where BCT comes in. Volunteers
and team-leads help conduct helplines, awareness sessions, blood donation camps, funding ses-
sions, health checkups, et cetera. Working with BCT is immensely fulfilling and directly contrib-
utes to the welfare of society. BloodConnect organises camps on most major festivals and na-
tional holidays. In its heyday, BloodConnect even had a fest of its own!

P.S- Rumour has it that no member of BloodConnect has less than 150 NSS hours on clock. Make of that what

you will!

Genesis 2024 | 29

NRVCEE-

The National Resource Centre for Value Education in Engineering (NRCVEE) was established with
the motto, “Integrity without knowledge is weak and useless, but knowledge without integrity is dangerous
and dreadful”. Its fundamental missions include undertaking research to understand human
potential and well-being, rendering evidence-based findings with both micro and macro level
implications and developing techniques which motivate engineers and students to imbibe
human values and appreciate their impact on technology development. NRCVEE conducts
seminars, workshops, and meditation events on campus, as a result of which students get to
meet a lot of IIT Delhi professors and alumni so even if you're not so interested in tech, do
give it a go because who knows, you might just get that boost you've been looking for your
influencer career through a podcast with Amol Parashar!

AINA-

The formation of AINA, An Initiative for National Advancement, was inspired by the conviction of
a small group of volunteers from IIT Delhi who believed that the world's peril did not arise
from the actions of malicious people, but rather from the absence of the proactive
involvement of a few virtuous ones. AINA has three popular activities that it organises across
the year-

1. Swadesh is an opportunity to work for the people living in the rural areas in different parts
of this country.

2. Manthan is a discussion on various socio-philosophical topics and values revolving around
a student's life.

3.

Srijan is a weekly trip to the slums of Munirka for the holistic development and education
of the children present there.

This academic year, AINA also hosted Sahbhoj, a community engagement programme
involving a food collection drive culminating into a collective feast of Dal Chawal in Munirka.

‘i

IRSC-

The Indian Road Safety Campaign (IRSC) originated as a project within the National Service
Scheme at IIT Delhi, in response to the tragic loss of students’ lives ina road accident.
Determined to prevent further tragedies, a team of students and faculty initiated the
campaign with the goal of making Indian roads safer. Under the guidance of the Transport
Research and Injury Prevention Program, the campaign has grown into a youth-led mission,
supported by students from colleges nationwide (10 states and 50+ cities). As an initiative
of SOLVE (pun intended), a trust established by IIT Delhi students and alumni to solve ground
level societal problems, IRSC strives to reduce road accidents by half before 2030 through
comprehensive measures addressing awareness, infrastructure, and emergency response.

 

 

IGES - Initiative for Gender
Equity and Sensitisation

    
   
 
 
 
 
   
   
   
  
  
   

IGES is the gender initiative and support cell of IIT Delhi, and it was
announced officially in March 2018 on the occasion of International
Women’s Day. Gender is something you experience and is not limited
to being a man or a woman; this idea is rooted deeply in the initiatives
taken by IGES. They aim to be a non-judgmental and safe space for
students, staff, and faculty members to allow them to share their
thoughts, concerns, anxieties, incidents, or evendilemmas related to
their gender and sexuality. They also providesocial support directly or
through referrals (confidentiality is always maintained).

This group also organises film screenings, thematic discussions and
debates, and many other events to create awareness. Moreover,
workshops for gender awareness and the prevention of sexual
harassment are regularly conducted for all cohorts of the institute
community. IGES also promotes conversations with multiple
stakeholders to understand the gender-related challenges restricting
an individual's access, career, and leadership in STEM fields. The aim is
to mainstream gender and equity perspectives in the institute’s vision,
planning, and day-to-day functioning.

ICE - Initiative for Caste Equity =

oS

IIT Delhi is committed to a friendly, discrimination-free and a
unbiased environment for everyone. Initiative for Caste Equity

(ICE) is responsible for educating the campus community about e

the significance of equality and diversity in building an equitable nD

environment. mS

5

The main purpose of the ICE is to ensure that no one is om

discriminated against on the basis of caste. As a policy, the an)

category status of the students, i.e, SC/ST/OBC/EWS/Gen, bam

should not be disclosed in the hostel or the classroom. The entire °

student community resides and dines together. A senior faculty 5

member is appointed as an advisor to SC/ST students to advise om

. . Sepa

them on academic and non-academic matters. oO

ICE also organises various outreach programmes like seminars,
workshops, film screenings, plays and discussions on caste
privileges, discrimination, and awareness. In addition, it
conducts mock interviews for final year SC/ST students to help
with their placements, strengthens coordination between the
work of the SC/ST Liaison Officer and the Student Advisor
and connects with SC/ST cells of other IITs.

Genesis 2024 | 31

Indhradhanu

Indradhanu-the LGBTQIA+ collective at IIT Delhi under the
Office of Diversity & Inclusion (ODI) that aims to make the
campus more inclusive, one rainbow at a time.

Their mission is to raise awareness about the beauty of
gender and sexual minorities. Indradhanu helps create a
safe space for everyone to explore, socialise, and learn
together, surrounded by love and acceptance.

They collaborate with the bigwigs at the institute to shape
policies that respect and protect LGBTQIA+ rights.
Indradhanu is one of India's largest Student-driven Queer
Collectives, with more than 215+ members. On the national
stage, by being a part of the Pan IIT petitioners’ group that
challenged the constitutional validity of Indian Penal Code
377 (a provision that criminalised homosexuality).
Indradhanu endeavours to make IIT Delhi strive toward the
intersectional causes of social justice, equality, and
freedom.

They hosted the first IIT All India Queer Collective
Conference during Vibhinn (IIT Delhi's Pride Festival) 2023.

Bisexual are attracted to both males and females,
Transgender, whose gender expressions are different from
what is associated with their sex

Queer explore their own sexual orientation or gender identity
Intersex possess one or more innate sex characteristics that
do not fit typical binary definitions of male or female
Asexual don’t experience any sexual attraction

+ symbolizes the inclusivity of all the incredible identities
that may not be explicitly covered in the acronym

and celebrate this diversity

OAE - Office of .
Accessible Education

The Office of Accessible Education (OAE) caters to the
needs of persons with disabilities in order to create an
environment where everyone can succeed and contribute
to the best of their abilities. Some individuals face unique

present on campus. It also
aims to create an inclusive
environment where every-
one feels safe and welcome.

 

 

challenges and barriers in their daily activities. OAE identifies
and addresses these barriers, allowing them to participate
fully in educational activities to make their journey at IIT Delhi
comfortable and hassle-free.

Special assistance

varying from academics to infrastructure requirements is
taken care of by the department.

The services provided by OAE include assistive technology
resources (Hardware and Software), study material in an
accessible format, scribe and compensatory time,
e-Rikshaw and wheelchair facility for moving across the IITD
campus and training of various assistive technologies.

32 | Genesis 2024

  
  
  
  

We know that it wouldn't be even a month
here in IITD, and you would be planning
many fun activities with your friends, but
amidst all the fun, drawing a boundary
between what is ethical and what's not is
very important.

As you navigate your confusing life at IIT Delhi,
you would be planning to indulge in many
fun activities, but amidst all the fun, remember
the Code of Honor, which you signed before
joining, and you should be thoroughly familiar
with the repercussions if there is some violation in
code. Simply put, whenever you try to break the
code, you are in danger of DisCo. Even though the word
itself doesn’t give you chills as it should have, DisCo or
Disciplinary Committee is not another badge you want to
acquire.

The effects of DisCo could be pretty majestic, and your college life
would be forever doomed just because of your slightest
misjudgments. The easiest way the prof can punish you is by
messing with your marks, which can impact your CGPA
significantly. You won't be allowed to hold any PORs (Position of
Responsibility) in your entire tenure at IIT, which can result in a
blank CV. For freshers, you would be barred from applying for a
DepC or department change, a ubiquitous goal of freshers. Your
hostel may get shifted in the next year or so, and sometimes your
hostel facilities can be abandoned throughout your stay here. So,
between all the different avenues you explore, it would be wise to
leave this one stone unturned.

honour code
of DisCo b

the line of breaking the
and escaping the doors
failed miserably.

cheating sounds, it can

of summer ‘23, many

In ELL101, many intellectuals made
an attempt to evade the rules in quizzes;
however, things didn’t go as they planned, as the
quizzes where cheating was suspected were
cancelled and retaken; moreover, the over-
smarts were on the brink of DisCo, only to be
spared by Profs mercy. This isn’t the professor's
first rodeo, and any attempt at breaking the
honour code will land you in hot water. In 2018
students were DisCo-ed for copying code from
senior year. Not only were the students who
copied the code punished but the senior who had
submitted the code previously was _ also
punished. You are very much advised to not only
copy someone's else work but also not to forward
NolU lee

 

“NEVER try to outsmart profs” . This advice will
come in handy after we tell you about the
following incident, which happened back in 2019
when a prof received a lewd and vulgar email
from an anonymous account. However, it took less
than 20 minutes for him to find out its source and
less than five more minutes to send the student to
Bee)
The main highlight of the incident was somewhat
the next mail which was released afterwards; the
summary of that mail was, “If you want to know
how | did it, you are welcome to take my course on
computer security”. Remember, if you think you are
smart, the profs have been there for years and seen
all kinds of foul activities you can imagine. Hence, it
would be better not to mess it up and add the
unnecessary badge of DisCo to your portfolio.

Gyan or RDV, the “Koh-i-Noor’” of IITD culture,

where all the BRCA clubs showcase their prowess to
lure hundreds of thousands of people from around
the Delhi daily. But during the RDV 2023, despite
having tight security, some event enthusiasts tried
to help their friends to get in the second pronite
without passes. They used cheap tricks like misusing
their IDs and forcing their way in. The event soon
turned out to be a disaster as this nugatory chaos
soon got into a stampede, ultimately cancelling the
second and even the third-day pronite.

Here, the
safety of students was taken as the utmost priority,
which left no choice but to call off the third pronite.
To summarise, IITD prioritises the safety of their
students the most, and any sneaky plans which can
undermine their security will be caught and severely
punished.

Whatever may be the flavour of the adrenaline
when you cross these lines, trust us, it will not be
worth the bitter aftertaste of DisCo. These four
years are your own journey to write, just don’t
blot the paper with the spot of DisCo. Eat your
vegetables, stay in school college and remember,
don't do drugs.
